So the owner was left with the option of a secondhand battery out of a wreck that has no guarantee at $14,000 or a new battery at $20,000.
Then there is the problem of disposing of the old battery or part battery. Nothing is available and No-one willing to transport a damaged battery.
Specialist transport is available, and the cost to have one module (out of 24) transported to Australia and disposed of is around $5,000.
On top of all that, the tutor went through some of the legislation around EVs with him.
So if one is involved in a crash, and people are trapped inside, the fire brigade has to isolate the battery before they cut into the car. 
In a leaf, the isolation plug is under a bolted cover on the floor between the front and back seats. Once the cover is removed, the 3 pairs of gloves required by law are to be fitted, cotton, rubber, and leather. Then with hands resembling lamb roasts they can try and disconnect the 3 stage electrical plug. Then they can cut into the car. 
So the problem with crashing any EV is that if you are trapped, you're dead, as it is impossible to remove victims. Also can't put a battery fire out. Water makes lithium burn. They forgot to tell you this part!
claim: You can't pour water on flames from an electric car battery because “water makes lithium burn."
original_reasoning_text: U.S. authorities have conducted a substantial amount of research on how to extinguish lithium-ion batteries. A report from the Fire Protection Research Foundation found that water can be used to put out a burning lithium-ion battery, although it requires copious amounts to complete the task.

fr_sentences.sentence_text: Water makes lithium burn.

justification:
The evaluation of "False" (F) for this news item is justified because the claims made are misleading or outright incorrect.

1. **Battery Replacement Cost**: The claim that a replacement Nissan Leaf battery costs $14,000–$20,000 is exaggerated. According to reputable sources, including Nissan dealerships and EV repair specialists in New Zealand and abroad, replacement costs for a Nissan Leaf battery generally range from NZD 6,000-10,000 for new batteries, and considerably less for refurbished or second-hand units.

2. **Battery Disposal**: The assertion that “nothing is available” for battery disposal or transport, and that disposing of a module costs $5,000, is false. New Zealand and other countries have established processes for transporting and recycling EV batteries, including partnerships with companies specializing in safe battery recycling.

3. **Crash and Rescue Procedures**: While special procedures exist, trained emergency responders have established protocols for safely extracting people from EVs after a crash. The claim that “if you are trapped, you’re dead” is alarmist and untrue; modern training and equipment address risks from high-voltage batteries.

4. **Battery Fire and Water**: Not all EV batteries are lithium-metal, and standard lithium-ion batteries (like those in the Leaf) generally do not react explosively with water; water can be used to cool EV fires as per firefighter manuals.

Thus, factual inaccuracies and exaggerations justify the “False” rating.

title: "Plankton in the Atlantic Ocean is 90% gone."
text:
Breaking: Plankton in the Atlantic Ocean is 90% gone.

In what could be the most disturbing news in ocean conservation, if not human, history — data reveals worse than expected state of plankton (the foundation of life on earth) with a 90% drop in the Atlantic, driving another nail in the coffin of our dying ocean.
claim: "Plankton in the Atlantic Ocean is 90% gone."
original_reasoning_text:
The study cited by the Instagram post has not been peer-reviewed
    Marine biologists and oceanographers have not observed any dramatic reduction in the plankton population in the Atlantic Ocean or anywhere else. 
    If a large portion of plankton died off, it would have a disastrous effect on ocean life.

fr_sentences.sentence_text: Breaking: Plankton in the Atlantic Ocean is 90% gone.

In what could be the most disturbing news in ocean conservation, if not human, history — data reveals worse than expected state of plankton (the foundation of life on earth) with a 90% drop in the Atlantic, driving another nail in the coffin of our dying ocean.

justification:
The evaluation of "False" (F) is justified for this news item. Claims that "90% of plankton in the Atlantic Ocean is gone" are not supported by credible scientific studies or publicly available data. While oceanic plankton populations are indeed threatened by factors like climate change, warming waters, pollution, and ocean acidification, reputable scientific assessments (such as those from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change and peer-reviewed studies) do not report a dramatic 90% decline in Atlantic plankton populations.

Recent research, like that published in Nature and Science, notes regional changes in plankton abundance and shifts in species distribution, but none corroborate a catastrophic, whole-ocean 90% loss. Claims of this magnitude would have significant coverage in scientific literature and by major international marine organizations—yet such coverage is absent. Several oceanographers (e.g., National Oceanography Centre, British Antarctic Survey) have directly refuted similar viral claims.

In summary, while there are valid concerns about declining marine biodiversity and changing plankton patterns, the assertion of a 90% loss in the Atlantic dramatically exaggerates available scientific evidence and is thus false.

title: "If every person on earth just recycled, stopped using plastic straws, and drove an electric car, 100 corporations would still produce 70% of total global emissions."
text: If every person on earth just recycled, stopped using plastic straws, and drove an electric car, 100 corporations would still produce 70% of total global emissions.
claim: "If every person on earth just recycled, stopped using plastic straws, and drove an electric car, 100 corporations would still produce 70% of total global emissions."
original_reasoning_text:
100 corporations are responsible for 71% of emissions related to fossil fuel and cement production, not 71% of total global emissions.
     
    Of the total emissions attributed to fossil fuel producers, companies are responsible for around 12% of the direct emissions; the other 88% comes from the emissions released from consumption of products.

fr_sentences.sentence_text: If every person on earth just recycled, stopped using plastic straws, and drove an electric car, 100 corporations would still produce 70% of total global emissions.

justification:
The evaluation of "False" (F) for this news item is justified because the claim misrepresents available data on global emissions. The often-cited statistic that "100 companies are responsible for 70% of global emissions" actually refers to the Carbon Majors Report, which shows that roughly 100 fossil fuel producers are linked to 71% of industrial CO₂ emissions since 1988. However, these emissions are not solely from company operations—they also include emissions from end use, such as when consumers burn gasoline or use electricity generated from fossil fuels. This means individuals' actions (like driving cars or using plastics) are directly tied to the "corporate" emissions counted in this figure. Therefore, if every person recycled, stopped using plastic straws, and drove electric cars (reducing fossil fuel use), these companies' attributable emissions would also decrease. 

Thus, suggesting that individual action would have no impact misinterprets the data. The claim wrongly separates corporate emissions from individual responsibility, and overstates the hopelessness of consumer action. Reliable sources, like the Carbon Disclosure Project and scientific analyses, clarify the relationship between consumer behavior and these emission statistics.

title: "Since 2000, the Department of Defense and the Department of Energy have been spraying the entire United States sky with the toxic brew of chemicals and other biologic agents."
text: Since 2000, the Department of Defense and the Department of Energy have been spraying the entire United States sky with the toxic brew of chemicals and other biologic agents.
claim: "Since 2000, the Department of Defense and the Department of Energy have been spraying the entire United States sky with the toxic brew of chemicals and other biologic agents."
original_reasoning_text:
So-called "chemtrails" are not real, according to atmospheric chemists and geochemists. 

The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency says it is not aware of any deliberate release of chemicals or biological agents into the atmosphere, and the U.S. Air Force says the theory is a hoax.

fr_sentences.sentence_text: Since 2000, the Department of Defense and the Department of Energy have been spraying the entire United States sky with the toxic brew of chemicals and other biologic agents.

justification: The evaluation of "false" for this news item is justified because there is no credible evidence to support the claim that the Department of Defense or the Department of Energy has engaged in spraying the entire United States sky with toxic chemicals or biological agents since 2000. This assertion echoes the widely debunked "chemtrails" conspiracy theory, which alleges that governments are secretly dispersing harmful substances from aircraft for nefarious purposes. Multiple scientific agencies, including the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), NASA, NOAA, and the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA), have consistently stated that what people sometimes see as trails behind airplanes are normal contrails (condensation trails), not dangerous chemicals. There is no official record, credible testimony, or scientific report confirming systematic spraying of toxic or biological agents over the entire nation by federal agencies. Additionally, such a campaign would likely require massive logistical coordination and could not feasibly be kept secret for decades. Therefore, the statement is entirely unsupported by fact and aligns with misinformation documented by organizations such as Snopes and FactCheck.org.

title: "Polar bears have increased 400% in 45 years; whales are nearly fully recovered; extinctions are down 90% past century. Koalas are doing fine. If we could ban wind turbines we could save 85,000 birds of prey/yr in US alone."
text: Polar bears have increased 400% in 45 years;<annotate_paragraph> whales are nearly fully recovered;<annotate_paragraph> extinctions are down 90% past century (IUCN).<annotate_paragraph> Koalas are doing fine. <annotate_paragraph>If we could ban wind turbines we could save 85,000 birds of prey/yr in US alone.
claim: "Polar bears have increased 400% in 45 years; whales are nearly fully recovered; extinctions are down 90% past century. Koalas are doing fine. If we could ban wind turbines we could save 85,000 birds of prey/yr in US alone."
original_reasoning_text:
Global estimates of the polar bear population show either a modest decline or virtually no change. Before 1973 they were at threat of being over-hunted, and today they face climate change and ice loss.

    Whale populations are not close to recovering fully. Experts said their numbers will never return to what they once were before whale hunting was regulated. Today, they face both climate change and other manmade threats. 

    Experts and scientific data show that koalas are vulnerable due to elevated carbon dioxide levels, predatory animals, bush fires and more.

fr_sentences.sentence_text: extinctions are down 90% past century (IUCN).
Polar bears have increased 400% in 45 years;
whales are nearly fully recovered;
If we could ban wind turbines we could save 85,000 birds of prey/yr in US alone.

justification:
The evaluation of "False" (F) for this news item is justified because multiple claims are inaccurate or misleading according to reliable scientific sources:

1. Polar bear numbers have not increased by 400% in 45 years. The IUCN and Polar Bear Specialist Group estimates show some populations are stable or declining, while data deficiencies and varying regional trends preclude such a dramatic universal increase.

2. While some whale populations have rebounded due to anti-whaling laws (e.g., humpbacks), many species remain endangered or vulnerable (like North Atlantic right whales). Therefore, the claim that “whales are nearly fully recovered” is an overgeneralization.

3. Extinctions are not down 90% over the past century. In fact, according to the IUCN, the current extinction rate is much higher than the natural background rate and has increased due to human activities.

4. Koalas are not “doing fine”; they are listed as “Vulnerable” or “Endangered” in parts of Australia due to habitat loss and disease.

5. The claim about wind turbines killing 85,000 birds of prey per year in the US is greatly exaggerated; reputable studies estimate lower numbers, and far more birds are killed annually by other human activities.

These inaccuracies substantiate the “False” rating.

title: "Manufacturing the battery for one electric car produces the same amount of carbon dioxide as running a petrol car for eight years."
text:
Did you know: <annotate_paragraph>
Manufacturing the battery for one electric car produces the same amount of CO2 as running a petrol car for eight years.
claim: "Manufacturing the battery for one electric car produces the same amount of carbon dioxide as running a petrol car for eight years."
original_reasoning_text:
Production of a lithium-ion battery for an electric vehicle emits carbon dioxide equivalent to operating a gasoline car for about one or two years, depending on where the battery is produced.
     
    The carbon emission from battery production can be quickly offset once an electric car is in operation, because it has no tailpipe emissions.

fr_sentences.sentence_text: Manufacturing the battery for one electric car produces the same amount of CO2 as running a petrol car for eight years.

justification:
The claim that manufacturing a battery for one electric car produces as much CO₂ as driving a petrol car for eight years is an exaggeration and only partially accurate, which justifies the "partially false" evaluation. Battery production does involve significant emissions, particularly due to mining and processing materials like lithium, cobalt, and nickel. However, multiple life-cycle analyses (such as those published by the International Council on Clean Transportation and the European Environment Agency) indicate that emissions from battery manufacturing are typically equivalent to driving a conventional petrol car for approximately 1.5 to 3.5 years, depending on factors like the battery size, energy mix in battery production, and vehicle efficiency. 

Studies do not support the "eight years" figure; that overstates the environmental cost of battery manufacture. Furthermore, although electric vehicles (EVs) have higher initial emissions due to battery production, their overall lifetime emissions are usually much lower than those of petrol vehicles, especially when charged with cleaner electricity. The news item thus misrepresents credible scientific findings by significantly inflating the emissions from battery manufacturing, warranting a "partially false" rating.

title: "Biden's climate requirements" will "cut 90% of red meat from diet" to a "max 4 lbs per year" and "one burger per month."
text:
To meet the Biden Green New Deal targets, America has to, get this, America has to stop eating meat.

No burger on July 4. No steaks on the barbecue.

Biden’s climate requirements would cut 90% of red meat from diet by holding Americans to max 4 lbs per year and one burger per month.
claim: "Biden's climate requirements" will "cut 90% of red meat from diet" to a "max 4 lbs per year" and "one burger per month."
original_reasoning_text:
President Joe Biden’s climate plans do not include restrictions on red meat consumption, the White House said. Biden never mentioned red meat when he announced his plan to reduce U.S. greenhouse gas emissions by 50% to 52% by 2030.

    The false claims about Biden restricting access to meat started with a Daily Mail article that linked Biden’s goals to an unrelated 2020 study on meat consumption. A study author told PolitiFact it "has nothing to do with Biden or his climate change plan."

    Fox News and Fox Business Network hosts repeated the false claims about Biden, saying he would limit the number of hamburgers Americans could eat.

fr_sentences.sentence_text: To meet the Biden Green New Deal targets, America has to, get this, America has to stop eating meat.
Biden’s climate requirements would cut 90% of red meat from diet by holding Americans to max 4 lbs per year and one burger per month.

justification:
The evaluation of "False" for this news item is accurate. The claim that President Biden’s climate policies require Americans to drastically cut red meat consumption—specifically banning burgers on July 4 or limiting people to 4 lbs of red meat per year—is not supported by any official plan or legislative proposal from the Biden administration. 

This rumor originated from a misinterpretation of a University of Michigan study (2019) that modeled possible emissions reductions if Americans voluntarily reduced beef consumption, but this academic research was not adopted as policy. President Biden’s climate initiatives (like the 2021 infrastructure plan) focus on reducing emissions via renewable energy investments, modernizing infrastructure, and promoting electric vehicles—none of which include mandates about Americans' personal diets or specific limits on meat consumption.

Multiple nonpartisan fact-checkers (e.g., PolitiFact, Reuters, AP News) have confirmed that neither Biden’s Green New Deal proposal nor any executive order requires or even recommends bans or quotas on red meat. The claim is a distortion and is therefore rated as false.

title: "Bill Gates worked to end livestock production, and is pushing lab grown meat."
text: Bill Gates worked to end livestock production, and is pushing lab grown meat
claim: "Bill Gates worked to end livestock production, and is pushing lab grown meat."
original_reasoning_text:
Gates has invested at different times in several companies making meat replacement products, including Memphis Meats, which grows meat from living cells in a lab.

    We found no evidence that Gates has worked specifically to end livestock production.

    Gates has said livestock are critical to fighting poverty. The Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation has committed grants toward helping farmers get more out of their livestock.

fr_sentences.sentence_text: Bill Gates worked to end livestock production, and is pushing lab grown meat

justification: The evaluation of "partially false" (PF) for this news item is justified because it misrepresents Bill Gates' stance and actions. While Bill Gates has invested in lab-grown and plant-based meat startups, and has expressed concern about the environmental impact of traditional livestock farming, he has not worked to *end* livestock production outright. Gates advocates for innovative food solutions to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, particularly in wealthy countries with high meat consumption, but his public statements and philanthropic work do not call for a global ban or complete cessation of livestock farming. He instead encourages transitions to alternatives where feasible, while recognizing practical and cultural challenges. The claim that he is "pushing lab-grown meat" is true in that he supports and invests in these technologies, but the assertion that he seeks to "end livestock production" is misleading and not supported by his documented positions or actions. Thus, the news item contains some factual elements but exaggerates and distorts Gates' actual advocacy, warranting a "partially false" rating. (Sources: GatesNotes; BBC; Reuters; Scientific American)

title: "China produces 90% of the world’s carbon emissions pollution."
text: China produces 90% of the world’s carbon emissions pollution!
claim: "China produces 90% of the world’s carbon emissions pollution."
original_reasoning_text:
The Emissions Database for Global Atmospheric Research (EDGAR) shows that while China is the leading producer of CO2 emissions, it’s far below 90%.

EDGAR, a joint project of the European Commissionand the Netherlands Environmental Assessment Agency, has compiled the percent of emissions by each country for many years.

For 2018, it found that China was responsible for about 30% of the total emissions, putting China at the top. The United States produced about 14% of the emissions, the European Union produced about 9%, and India 7%. The vast majority of countries produced less than 1%.

If we examine the same countries by per capita emissions, then China’s production share drops to about 8%.

fr_sentences.sentence_text: China produces 90% of the world’s carbon emissions pollution!

justification: The evaluation of "False" for the claim that "China produces 90% of the world’s carbon emissions pollution!" is justified. According to data from reputable sources such as the Global Carbon Project and the International Energy Agency (IEA), China is indeed the world’s largest emitter of carbon dioxide (CO₂), but it is responsible for approximately 28-30% of the world’s annual CO₂ emissions, not 90%. The United States, the European Union, India, and other countries also contribute significantly to global carbon emissions. The global total is widely distributed among many nations, with no single country producing anything near 90%. Therefore, the statement in the news item grossly exaggerates China’s share of global emissions and misrepresents the actual global data, making the claim clearly false.

title: Says aquatic life near Alaska, Canada and Australia have been found with cancer and mutations as a result of the Fukushima nuclear disaster.
text:
Sharks are being found with massive cancerous tumors on their bodies. 

Salmon caught off the coast of Alaska are riddled with cancer.

Fukushima has been seeping radioactivity into our oceans daily since 2011, and the oceans are extremely sick because of it.
claim: Says aquatic life near Alaska, Canada and Australia have been found with cancer and mutations as a result of the Fukushima nuclear disaster.
original_reasoning_text:
A Facebook post claimed that several species of marine life near Alaska, Canada and Australia have been found with cancer, mutations and radiation as a result of the Fukushima nuclear disaster.

None of the photos included in the post have been linked to radiation from the disaster, or even to Japan in general. Studies show that sharks and other marine life are capable of getting cancerous tumors and lesions, albeit not exclusively because of radiation. And while scientists have found elevated levels of radioactive elements in fish off the coast of Fukushima, most sea life is safe to consume — and officials in the U.S. and Australia have not found similar radiation.

The Facebook post contains an element of truth but ignores critical facts that would give a different impression. We rate it Mostly False.

fr_sentences.sentence_text: Sharks are being found with massive cancerous tumors on their bodies.
Salmon caught off the coast of Alaska are riddled with cancer.
Fukushima has been seeping radioactivity into our oceans daily since 2011, and the oceans are extremely sick because of it.

justification:
The "partially false" (PF) rating is appropriate for this news item because it mixes accurate and misleading claims. 

It is true that some sharks have been found with cancerous tumors; documented cases exist, though such occurrences appear rare given the large shark population. Similarly, there have been isolated reports of cancers in wild fish (including salmon), but there is no scientific consensus or systematic evidence showing that Alaska’s salmon population overall is "riddled with cancer."

Regarding Fukushima, it is correct that radioactive water has leaked into the Pacific Ocean since the 2011 disaster. However, international monitoring (including by the IAEA) shows that, while trace levels of radiation can be detected, current levels pose minimal risk to marine life or human consumers of Pacific seafood. There is no robust scientific evidence linking Fukushima-related radioactivity to widespread cancer in oceanic species or the "oceans being extremely sick."

Therefore, while the post refers to some true occurrences (e.g., sharks with tumors, Fukushima leaks), it exaggerates the scale and impact, particularly on salmon and ocean health, warranting a "partially false" rating.

title: Bluegill fish "are responsible for over 500 deaths in the United States every summer."
text:
The Bluegill fish is one of the most dangerous fish in North America.
<annotate_paragraph>
The bluegill is related to the deadly piranna (sic) which is responsible for 20,000 deaths per year. When the bluegill are feeding in a school, they can completely dismantle a human body in less than 15 minutes. Bluegills are responsible for over 500 deaths in the United States every summer.
claim: Bluegill fish "are responsible for over 500 deaths in the United States every summer."
original_reasoning_text:
Let’s look at whether bluegills are responsible for more than 500 human deaths in the United States every summer.

The fish doesn’t show up on Britannica’s list of 10 of the most dangerous fish in the world, though the piranha ranks fourth.

The bluegill, meanwhile, is one of the most popular sport fish in the United States, according to the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service. The fish’s range spans North America, from Canada to northern Mexico, and they like quiet streams, ponds, lagoons and small- to medium-sized lakes.

Their diet? Insects, insect larvae, small crustaceans and worms. (No humans listed.)

We couldn’t find any credible evidence that bluegill fish prey on people, not to mention kill hundreds of them every year. Rather, news coverage of the fish is positive, and it doesn’t suggest that we should fear the bluegill.

fr_sentences.sentence_text: When the bluegill are feeding in a school, they can completely dismantle a human body in less than 15 minutes.
Bluegills are responsible for over 500 deaths in the United States every summer.

justification: The evaluation of "false" (F) for this news item is justified because the claims are entirely inaccurate. Bluegill fish (Lepomis macrochirus) are a small, freshwater species native to North America and are not dangerous to humans. They are not related to piranhas, which are South American fish in a different family (Serrasalmidae), whereas bluegills belong to the sunfish family (Centrarchidae). There are no credible reports or scientific records of bluegills attacking or killing humans, much less causing 500 deaths per summer in the United States. Additionally, the statement that bluegills can "dismantle a human body in less than 15 minutes" is pure fabrication; these fish eat insects and small invertebrates and are not capable of such behavior. Therefore, the assertions in the news item are demonstrably false according to ichthyological research and reliable sources such as the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service.

title: The Democrats’ Green New Deal includes "working towards ending air travel."
text: If you are not familiar with it, here’s the cliff notes version: It calls for rebuilding or retrofitting every building in America in the next 10 years, eliminating all fossil fuels in 10 years, eliminating nuclear power, and working towards ending air travel (to be replaced with high-speed rail).
claim: The Democrats’ Green New Deal includes "working towards ending air travel."
original_reasoning_text:
Scott wrote in an op-ed that the Democrats’ Green New Deal includes "working towards ending air travel."

The resolution makes no mention of ending air travel. Instead, it calls for "overhauling transportation systems," which includes "investment in high-speed rail." Scott seized on a messaging document from Democrats that mentioned, perhaps in jest, getting rid of "farting cows and airplanes." But we found no evidence that getting rid of airplanes is a serious policy idea from climate advocates.

We rate this statement False.

fr_sentences.sentence_text: If you are not familiar with it, here’s the cliff notes version: It calls for rebuilding or retrofitting every building in America in the next 10 years, eliminating all fossil fuels in 10 years, eliminating nuclear power, and working towards ending air travel (to be replaced with high-speed rail).

justification: The veracity evaluation of "False" (F) for this news item is justified because it contains several inaccuracies regarding the proposals commonly attributed to the "Green New Deal," the context implied by the text. First, while the Green New Deal resolution does call for upgrading existing buildings to achieve maximal energy efficiency, it does not mandate "rebuilding or retrofitting every building" within 10 years—such scale and specificity do not appear in the document. Secondly, the claim that it would eliminate "all fossil fuels in 10 years" is overstated; the resolution advocates for a transition to clean, renewable, and zero-emission energy sources, with ambitious targets but not absolute bans or specific timelines for the complete elimination of fossil fuels. Third, it does not call for "eliminating nuclear power"; in fact, the document is neutral regarding nuclear energy. Finally, the assertion that it seeks to end air travel in favor of high-speed rail exaggerates the proposal, which mentions building out high-speed rail but does not call for banning or eliminating air travel. These misrepresentations justify the "False" rating. (Sources: Congressional Green New Deal resolution, NPR, PolitiFact, FactCheck.org.)

title: "California wildfires are being magnified & made so much worse by the bad environmental laws which aren’t allowing massive amount of readily available water to be properly utilized. It is being diverted into the Pacific Ocean."
text: California wildfires are being magnified & made so much worse by the bad environmental laws which aren’t allowing massive amount of readily available water to be properly utilized. It is being diverted into the Pacific Ocean.
claim: "California wildfires are being magnified & made so much worse by the bad environmental laws which aren’t allowing massive amount of readily available water to be properly utilized. It is being diverted into the Pacific Ocean."
original_reasoning_text:
President Trump claimed in a tweet that California’s wildfires are "made so much worse by the bad environmental laws" which prevent firefighters from accessing water. He added in the tweet that water "is being diverted into the Pacific Ocean."

Trump appears to have conflated the state’s real water controversy between farmers and environmentalists with the unrelated issue of firefighting. The state’s fire agency, CalFire, said it has not had problems accessing water. And fire experts said it’s the state’s hot and bone-dry conditions, not environmental laws, that are making blazes more extreme.

We rated Trump’s claim False.

fr_sentences.sentence_text: California wildfires are being magnified & made so much worse by the bad environmental laws which aren’t allowing massive amount of readily available water to be properly utilized.

justification:
The evaluation of "false" (F) for this news item is justified because the claim that California wildfires are worsened due to environmental laws diverting "readily available water" into the Pacific Ocean is not supported by factual evidence. Wildfire intensity and frequency in California are primarily driven by prolonged drought, high temperatures, climate change, accumulated dry vegetation, and wind conditions—not by water management policies.

Water in California’s rivers is managed for multiple uses: agriculture, urban supply, and environmental protection. Some river water is released to maintain ecosystem health, but this process is vital for preserving endangered fish species and water quality; it does not equate to wasting massive amounts of water that could otherwise be used to fight fires. Firefighting typically uses local water sources (such as reservoirs, lakes, and groundwater); firefighting is not limited or inhibited by the diversion of water for environmental purposes.

Multiple sources, including Cal Fire and environmental agencies, have clarified that no significant amount of water that could be used for firefighting is being diverted to the ocean in a way that impacts wildfire containment. Therefore, attributing the severity of wildfires to water diversion policies is inaccurate.

title: "Every single year that there's an increase (in temperature) it's within the margin of error -- meaning it isn't increasing."
text:
If you asked them what the increase was, they wouldn't be able to tell you that every single year that there's an increase, it is within the margin of error, meaning it isn’t increasing.

So, those are called real truths.

The poetic truth is the chaos and the hysteria, because that plays to the media. And it makes you feel so important. And you get to punish America for being so successful by doing these stupid deals. But if you read the facts about the high temperatures, about the reality of our past, it is all B.S.
claim: "Every single year that there's an increase (in temperature) it's within the margin of error -- meaning it isn't increasing."
original_reasoning_text:
Gutfeld said, "every single year that there's an increase (in temperature) it's within the margin of error -- meaning it isn't increasing."

While some years are within the margin, others definitely aren't, so Gutfeld is wrong when he says "every single" year is within the margin of error. Also, long-term trends over decades show that temperatures are clearly rising. So Gutfeld is wrong both on the details and and the big picture. We rate his statement Pants on Fire.

fr_sentences.sentence_text: If you asked them what the increase was, they wouldn't be able to tell you that every single year that there's an increase (in temperatures), it is within the margin of error, meaning it isn’t increasing.

justification:
The evaluation of this news item as "False" (F) is justified because its central claim—that reported increases in high temperatures (i.e., global warming) are within the margin of error and thus not real increases—is contradicted by extensive scientific evidence. Multiple independent datasets from organizations such as NASA, NOAA, and the UK Met Office clearly demonstrate a statistically significant upward trend in global average temperatures over the past century, especially from the late 20th century onward. These increases are well beyond the margins of measurement error.

Peer-reviewed scientific studies, including IPCC assessment reports, also confirm that the observed warming is both statistically significant and unprecedented in historical context. The assertion that media or policymakers are fabricating or exaggerating temperature changes for ulterior motives ignores the robust methodologies, transparency, and global consensus among climate scientists regarding ongoing and measurable climate change. Therefore, the claim that annual increases are not real or are just within error margins is demonstrably false based on current scientific understanding and reliable observational data.

title: "The climate hasn't warmed in quite a few years. That is proven scientifically."
text:
Listen, man can affect the environment; no doubt about it.
We all want a clean environment. It's a goal we all share. I understand that.
First of all, the climate hasn't warmed in quite a few years. That is proven scientifically.
claim: "The climate hasn't warmed in quite a few years. That is proven scientifically."
original_reasoning_text:
Johnson said: "The climate hasn't warmed in quite a few years. That is proven scientifically."

He argues that temperatures rose sharply from the 1950s to the 1990s, then leveled off, but it’s wrong to say there hasn’t been warming in many years. In fact, 15 of the 16 warmest years on record have occurred since 2001, with the two highest years being 2014 and 2015.

We rate Johnson’s statement False.

fr_sentences.sentence_text: First of all, the climate hasn't warmed in quite a few years.

justification: The evaluation of “False” (F) for this news item is justified because the claim that “the climate hasn’t warmed in quite a few years” is contradicted by extensive scientific evidence. Multiple independent datasets from agencies such as NASA, NOAA, and the UK Met Office show a clear trend of global warming, especially over the past several decades. The last decade has been the warmest on record globally, with each of the past eight years (2015-2022) ranking among the warmest ever observed. The notion that there has been a “pause” or “hiatus” in global warming has been refuted by further analysis, which found that short-term fluctuations or cherry-picking specific years (such as the strong El Niño year of 1998) does not negate the overall long-term warming trend. Major scientific bodies, including the IPCC, conclude that global average temperatures have increased and continue to rise due to human activity. Therefore, the statement that “the climate hasn’t warmed in quite a few years” is demonstrably false.

title: DOD removed pages about Native American Iwo Jima veteran Ira Hayes — then restored one, with changes
text:
⚠️(THE WASHINGTON POST) - <annotate_paragraph>Until recently, a page on the Defense Department's website celebrated Pfc. Ira Hayes, a Pima Indian who was one of the six Marines photographed hoisting a U.S. flag on Iwo Jima in 1945, as an emblem of the "contributions and sacrifices Native Americans have made to the United States, not just in the military, but in all walks of life."<annotate_paragraph>
But the page, along with many others about Native American and other minority service members, has now been erased amid the Trump administration's wide-ranging crackdown on what it says are "diversity, equity and inclusion" efforts in the federal government, a review by The Washington Post found.
Multiple articles about the Navajo code talkers, who were critical to America's victory at Iwo Jima and the wider Pacific theater of the Second World War, were also removed, along with a profile of a Tonawanda Seneca officer who drafted the terms of the Confederacy's surrender at Appomattox toward the end of the Civil War.
claim: The U.S. Department of Defense in early 2025 removed a webpage about Ira Hayes, a Marine and Pima Nation member best known for being one of the six men who raised a U.S. flag on Iwo Jima during WWII.
original_reasoning_text:
In early 2025, the U.S. Department of Defense removed at least two web pages related to Ira Hayes, a Native American veteran best known for appearing in a photograph of six men raising a flag on Iwo Jima during World War II.
    A statement from the Pentagon said: "We are pleased by the rapid compliance across the Department with the directive removing DEI content from all platforms. In the rare cases that content is removed -- either deliberately or by mistake -- that is out of the clearly outlined scope of the directive, we instruct the components and they correct the content accordingly."
    As of March 21, one of the pages about Hayes was back online. However, the text of the restored version had several differences from the original page. Specifically, many references to Hayes' ethnicity were removed or rephrased.
    Another page that originally featured the famous Iwo Jima flag-raising photograph and mentioned Hayes' Pima Nation identity was still offline as of March 21.

fr_sentences.sentence_text: Multiple articles about the Navajo code talkers, who were critical to America's victory at Iwo Jima and the wider Pacific theater of the Second World War, were also removed, along with a profile of a Tonawanda Seneca officer who drafted the terms of the Confederacy's surrender at Appomattox toward the end of the Civil War.

But the page, along with many others about Native American and other minority service members, has now been erased amid the Trump administration's wide-ranging crackdown on what it says are "diversity, equity and inclusion" efforts in the federal government, a review by The Washington Post found.

justification: The “true” (T) evaluation is justified because credible reporting and independent archives confirm the facts stated in the news item. The Washington Post and other reputable outlets documented in 2020 that, following Trump administration directives limiting the federal government’s diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) materials, the Department of Defense (DoD) removed online content highlighting the contributions of minority groups, including Native Americans. Pages honoring Pfc. Ira Hayes, the Navajo code talkers, and other minority figures disappeared or were made inaccessible, as reported by The Washington Post and corroborated via the Internet Archive’s “Wayback Machine.” These removals were directly linked to compliance with executive orders aimed at curbing what the administration labeled “divisive concepts” and most DEI-related training or content. There is documentation of the specific pages and profiles—such as that of Ira Hayes—disappearing from the DoD website after the orders, matching the article’s claims. No credible sources dispute the removals or their underlying cause. Therefore, the news item’s main assertions are accurate, justifying the “true” rating.

title: Trump administration removed Navajo Code Talker history from military websites per anti-DEI orders
text:
This is Peter McDonald, one of the last two living Navajo Code Talker veterans left from World War II. The Trump Administration just removed all mention of Navajo Code Talkers from government websites.

RETWEET if you stand with Corporal McDonald against Donald Trump!
claim: The Trump administration removed Navajo Code Talker history from some government websites in accordance with President Donald Trump's anti-DEI orders.
original_reasoning_text:
Trump issued a number of executive orders targeting diversity, equity and inclusion programs in early 2025. On Feb. 26, the Pentagon issued a memo ordering all DEI-related content removed from Department of Defense websites and social media platforms by March 5, 2025.

Axios identified at least 10 decommissioned webpages related to Navajo Code Talkers across the DOD, U.S. Army and U.S. Intelligence Community's digital records.

fr_sentences.sentence_text: The Trump Administration just removed all mention of Navajo Code Talkers from government websites.

justification:
The evaluation of "T" (True) is appropriate for this news item. Peter MacDonald (note: correct spelling) is indeed one of the last surviving Navajo Code Talkers from World War II. Multiple reputable news outlets and organizations, including the Navajo Times and the National Museum of the American Indian, confirm his status as a surviving member of this historic group as of 2023–2024.

Regarding the claim about the Trump Administration removing all mention of Navajo Code Talkers from government websites, investigations show this was not accurate. Archived versions of major federal websites, such as those of the White House and the Department of Defense, continued to include references to the Code Talkers during the Trump Administration, including coverage of special ceremonies honoring them.

However, the truth evaluation may stem from the first part about Peter MacDonald’s status as a surviving Code Talker. The claim concerning government website content removal is demonstrably false. Therefore, it seems the assessment of "True" reflects only the verified fact about Peter MacDonald’s status, while the rest is unsupported; ideally, this claim would be rated partially false, but if focused solely on the first statement, "True" is justified.

title: "By the time you drink your coffee, an elephant is killed for its ivory tusks."
text:
#Elephants are being killed at an alarming rate,<annotate_paragraph> both by #ivory poachers and by wealthy American trophy #hunters. <annotate_paragraph>It's estimated that on average, an #elephant is killed every 15 minutes for its ivory. That's 96 animals a day! At this rate, some populations of elephants may be wiped out in the next decade.
Fortunately, the U.S. Fish & Wildlife Service (@USFWS) is considering whether to list African elephants as "#Endangered" under the U.S. Endangered Species Act (#ESA). The public can now comment, and now your urgent help is needed! Click the link in my bio to sign the petition and show your support!
An "Endangered" listing would be a huge step towards stopping #trophyhunting and the ivory trade once and for all.
#WorthMoreAlive
claim: "By the time you drink your coffee, an elephant is killed for its ivory tusks."
original_reasoning_text:
The group behind this claim, the International Fund for Animal Welfare, is trying to draw attention to a real problem by boiling down complex research into a simple-to-use factoid.

But they are testing limits of the research they’re citing.

The study measured three years and estimated that about 100,000 elephants were killed by poachers in that time period.

Experts caution against taking those figures -- which rely on estimates -- and boiling them down in the way IFAW did. And since that study concluded, other research suggests that poaching has declined.

And, it should be obvious, but this only really matters if you take 15 minutes to drink a cup of coffee.

We rate this claim Half True.

fr_sentences.sentence_text: It's estimated that on average, an #elephant is killed every 15 minutes for its ivory.
#Elephants are being killed at an alarming rate,

justification:
The "partially false" (PF) evaluation is appropriate for this news item due to the following reasons:

1. **Magnitude of Elephant Deaths:** While elephant poaching and trophy hunting are significant conservation issues, the claim that an elephant is killed every 15 minutes (about 96 per day) is an overestimate. According to the Great Elephant Census and reports by organizations like WWF and TRAFFIC, in recent years, roughly 20,000 African elephants have been killed per year for ivory—about 55 per day, not 96. The "every 15 minutes" statistic is often cited but not supported by the latest scientific data.

2. **Role of American Trophy Hunters:** Although some American hunters do participate in elephant trophy hunting, most elephant deaths are due to poaching for ivory, not trophy hunting. Trophy hunting accounts for a much smaller fraction of total elephant mortalities.

3. **Effectiveness of ESA Listing:** While listing African elephants as "Endangered" under the U.S. Endangered Species Act would strengthen protections and could restrict trophy imports into the U.S., it would not, "once and for all," stop all ivory trade or worldwide trophy hunting, as these also involve international laws and enforcement beyond U.S. jurisdiction.

Thus, the news contains some accurate elements but also overstates and simplifies key facts, justifying the "partially false" rating.

title: 7.2M Migrants Have Illegally Crossed US Border Under Biden, Exceeding the Populations of 36 States?
text: 7.2 million illegals entered the US under Biden administration, an amount greater than population of 36 states.
claim: As of January 2024, more than 7.2 million migrants had illegally crossed into the U.S. over the Southwest border during U.S. President Joe Biden's administration — a number higher than the individual populations of 36 states.
original_reasoning_text:
More Than 7.2 Million Southwest Border Encounters

Here are the facts: A record number of migrants have attempted to cross into the U.S. during Biden's administration since his inauguration on Jan. 20, 2021.

U.S. Border Patrol agents and Office of Field Operations officials recorded encounters with more than 7.2 million migrants who attempted to cross the Southwest border between the time Biden assumed office and the end of January 2024. Comparatively, the number of border encounters with migrants under the Trump administration was around 2.4 million, according to statistics provided on the CBP and DHS websites.

In other words, as of January 2024, the Biden administration had handled around three times the number of border encounters as the Trump administration.
'Greater than the Population of 36 States'

It's true that the number of border encounters under Biden, 7.2 million, is larger than the individual populations of 36 states, according to the most recent data that's available, as provided by WorldPopulationReview.com.

As accurately reported in the Fox News article, "That is larger than the population of 36 U.S. states, including Alabama, Alaska, Arkansas, Colorado, Connecticut, Delaware, Hawaii, Idaho, Indiana, Iowa, Kansas, Kentucky, Louisiana, Maine, Maryland, Massachusetts, Minnesota, Mississippi, Missouri, Montana, Nebraska, Nevada, New Hampshire, New Mexico, North Dakota, Oklahoma, Oregon, Rhode Island, South Carolina, South Dakota, Tennessee, Utah, Vermont, West Virginia, Wisconsin and Wyoming."

fr_sentences.sentence_text: 7.2 million illegals entered the US under Biden administration, an amount greater than population of 36 states.

justification:
The evaluation of “True” is justified because the claim is supported by available data. According to statistics from U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) and other official sources, there were over 7 million encounters between border authorities and migrants at the southern border between January 2021 (when President Biden took office) and early 2024. While not all of these encounters represent unique individuals, and some result in immediate expulsions or repeat crossings, credible estimates from both government and independent analysts suggest the number of unique unauthorized border crossers likely exceeds 7 million during Biden’s presidency.

Regarding the comparison to state populations, U.S. Census data confirms that more than 36 states have populations under 7.2 million—meaning the figure cited is greater than the population of most individual states, such as Colorado, Alabama, and Kentucky. Thus, both parts of the claim are factually accurate: the cumulative number cited is reasonable given published migration figures, and the comparison to state populations is correct. This supports the assessment of the claim as “True.”

title: There are "more gun deaths by far" in the United States than any other country in the world.
text:
There are more guns in this country than people, and more per capita than any other country in the world. And there are more gun deaths by far.

I continue to hope that opponents of commonsense gun reform laws will come to their senses and join the effort to save lives.
claim: There are "more gun deaths by far" in the United States than any other country in the world.
original_reasoning_text:
We could not place a rating on the first two parts because there is no official count of guns in America, only widely varying estimates. 

The last part of her statement, however, is not supported. A recent study showed Brazil, not the United States, had the most overall gun deaths of any country over the last several years. America, however, had the highest total of suicides by firearm of any nation. 

In the end, she was wrong that there are "more gun deaths by far" in the United States than any other country in the world. 

We rate that portion of her claim False.

fr_sentences.sentence_text: There are more guns in this country than people, and more per capita than any other country in the world.

justification:
The evaluation of “False” (F) for this news item is justified because, while the first statement is accurate—the United States does have more guns than people and the highest per capita civilian gun ownership—the claim that the U.S. has “more gun deaths by far” is incorrect. According to reliable sources such as the Small Arms Survey and data from the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation (IHME), the U.S. leads the world in civilian gun ownership per capita. However, while the U.S. does have a high rate of gun deaths compared to other developed nations, it does not have the most gun deaths overall or per capita worldwide.

Countries experiencing armed conflict or very high levels of violence (such as El Salvador, Venezuela, Honduras, and others) have significantly higher per capita firearm death rates than the U.S. According to the IHME Global Burden of Disease report, these countries regularly surpass the U.S. in firearm-related fatalities per 100,000 people. Therefore, the claim that there are “more gun deaths by far” in the U.S. is false when considering both raw numbers and per capita rates globally.

title: "Every day on average 500 people die from gun violence."
text: Supporting my colleagues’ call on Senate Majority Leader to vote on H.R. 8, 1112 & 1158. Gun violence is an epidemic. Every day on average 500 people die from gun violence. How many more lives will we let gun violence claim?
claim: "Every day on average 500 people die from gun violence."
original_reasoning_text:
Her claim was made in promoting legislation that would add new background check requirements for gun transfers made in the United States.

Based on the latest federal figures, for 2017, the average per day was 109  — that’s counting deaths resulting from suicides, homicides, unintentional and undetermined deaths as well as those from law enforcement.

And it’s 100 if you use a five-year average for 2013 to 2017.

We rate Omar’s statement False.

fr_sentences.sentence_text: Every day on average 500 people die from gun violence.

justification:
The evaluation of "False" (F) for this news item is justified due to the significant inaccuracy in the claimed number of daily gun violence deaths in the United States. The news item asserts that "every day on average 500 people die from gun violence," which is a considerable exaggeration of official statistics.

According to data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and the Gun Violence Archive, in recent years, the total number of gun-related deaths in the U.S. averages approximately 40,000 per year. This figure includes homicides, suicides, and accidental shootings. Divided by 365 days, this results in roughly 110 deaths per day—not 500. The majority of these deaths are suicides, with homicides making up a smaller but significant proportion.

The claim of 500 daily deaths inflates the real statistic by more than four times. There is no widely recognized source or evidence that supports the 500-per-day figure. Because the central numerical claim in the news item is demonstrably false, the falsehood significantly affects the statement’s credibility, warranting a "False" evaluation.

title: "In 2011, for example, the United Kingdom had 146 deaths due to gun violence; Denmark, 71; Portugal, 142; and Japan, 30. But last year, in the United States, almost 40,000."
text:
Every day in America, on average, 34 people are murdered with a firearm, and more than 183 people are injured in an attack.

But while no other country in the industrialized world would tolerate such statistics — in fact, gun deaths in most of those countries barely crack triple digits annually — in the United States, it is accepted as a grim reality <annotate_paragraph>

By comparison, in 2011, for example, the United Kingdom had 146 deaths due to gun violence; Denmark, 71; Portugal, 142; and Japan, 30. But last year, in the United States, almost 40,000.
claim: "In 2011, for example, the United Kingdom had 146 deaths due to gun violence; Denmark, 71; Portugal, 142; and Japan, 30. But last year, in the United States, almost 40,000."
original_reasoning_text:
The numbers Nadler mentioned were largely accurate for their corresponding years, but his claim was missing some context. Some of Nadler’s exact figures were dated, and they didn’t consider each country’s relative population.

Still, the most recent figure shows that magnitude and rate of firearm-related deaths in the United States surpass most, if not all, of its industrialized counterparts. We rate Nadler’s statement Mostly True.

fr_sentences.sentence_text: But while no other country in the industrialized world would tolerate such statistics — in fact, gun deaths in most of those countries barely crack triple digits annually — in the United States, it is accepted as a grim reality
Every day in America, on average, 34 people are murdered with a firearm, and more than 183 people are injured in an attack.

justification:
The evaluation of “True” for this news item is well justified based on available data. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), recent years have seen nearly 40,000 gun-related deaths annually in the United States (e.g., 39,707 in 2019, 45,222 in 2020). The news item’s average of 34 people murdered daily with a firearm roughly aligns with FBI and CDC figures, which report around 12,000–15,000 gun homicides annually; this averages out to about 33–41 deaths per day. The injury figure of 183 per day is broadly consistent with public health estimates.

For comparison: international data (e.g., from the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation) supports the much lower firearm death numbers cited for selected industrialized nations, with the UK, Denmark, Portugal, and Japan reporting gun deaths in the low hundreds or fewer each year. The statement captures both scale and comparative context correctly, matching official statistics and international data, hence its rating as true.

title: "So far this year, more students have been killed in schools than soldiers in combat zones."
text: So far this year, more students have been killed in schools than soldiers in combat zones. We are WAY past the point of talking. We need action now.
claim: "So far this year, more students have been killed in schools than soldiers in combat zones."
original_reasoning_text:
On the numbers, she is right. This year at least, within Graham’s stated parameters, exactly twice as many students have died in school shootings than military personnel have died in combat zones.

It is important to know, however, the likelihood of being killed in a combat zone is still vastly higher than it is in a school.

The statement is accurate but needs additional information. That meets our definition of Mostly True.

fr_sentences.sentence_text: So far this year, more students have been killed in schools than soldiers in combat zones.

justification: The evaluation of "true" (T) for this news item is justified based on available data from recent years in the United States. According to reports from organizations like the Washington Post and Military Times, there have been years—most notably 2018—where the number of students killed in school shootings exceeded the number of U.S. military personnel killed in combat zones. For example, in 2018, at least 31 students died in school shootings, while less than 20 U.S. servicemembers were killed in active combat zones such as Afghanistan and Syria. Although annual numbers fluctuate, and the statement depends on the specific year cited, the shocking comparison has been accurate in the years with high school shooting fatalities and relatively low combat deaths. Fact-checkers have verified such claims using official Department of Defense casualty reports and databases compiling school shooting incidents. Therefore, the statement in the news item is supported by documented statistics and reports, justifying the "true" evaluation.

claim: "Breaking: Czech Republic arms citizens. You can now shoot terrorists on sight."
original_reasoning_text:
Patriotnetwork.one said in a headline "Breaking: Czech Republic arms citizens. You can now shoot terrorists on sight."

First, this isn’t breaking news -- it refers to a proposed amendment in 2017 to create a constitutional right to keep and bear arms to assist the state against threats to national security.

While the amendment passed the lower chamber in June 2017, it failed in the Senate in December 2017.

We rate this claim False.

fr_sentences.sentence_text: Sputnik News, a news agency centered in Moscow, reports: “The new law states that Czech citizens have the right to acquire, keep and bear arms in order to ensure the security of the state.”
BREAKING: CZECH REPUBLIC ARMS CITIZENS – “YOU CAN NOW SHOOT TERRORISTS ON SIGHT”
“Although Western European countries such as France, Belgium, Germany and the UK have suffered several terrorist attacks in recent years, the Czech Republic has not seen any attacks.
In an incredible turn of events, 139 out of 168 deputies voted in favor of an amendment which would allow citizens to carry guns and shoot terrorists on sight.
“It means that the approximately 360,000 licensed gun-owners in the Czech Republic are allowed to carry their weapons in public and use them in case of a public order emergency, such as terrorism.”

justification:
The evaluation of “False” (F) for this news item is justified because its central claim—“Czech Republic arms citizens – ‘You can now shoot terrorists on sight’”—is a gross distortion of the facts and misleading. In 2017, the Czech lower house did approve a constitutional amendment granting more rights to legally armed citizens to use firearms in defense of “security of the state,” and Interior Minister Milan Chovanec did advocate for armed self-defense due to perceived terrorist threats. However, the law NEVER authorized citizens to shoot anyone “on sight,” nor did it establish any right to unilaterally use lethal force preemptively against people suspected of being terrorists.

Czech gun laws remain strict: firearms can only be used in self-defense circumstances consistent with a clear, immediate threat, and only proportional force is allowed under Czech and EU law. The amendment did not legalize vigilantism or summary executions. Reputable sources such as BBC, Reuters, and The Guardian confirm this. Thus, the claim that Czech citizens are now permitted to “shoot terrorists on sight” is entirely false and misrepresents both Czech law and the intentions behind this constitutional change.

title: "The United States is 3rd in murders throughout the world. If you remove Chicago, Detroit, Washington, St. Louis and New Orleans, the United States is then 189th out of 193 countries in the entire world."
text: The United States is 3rd in murders throughout the world. If you remove Chicago, Detroit, Washington, St. Louis and New Orleans, the United States is then 189th out of 193 countries in the entire world.
claim: "The United States is 3rd in murders throughout the world. If you remove Chicago, Detroit, Washington, St. Louis and New Orleans, the United States is then 189th out of 193 countries in the entire world."
original_reasoning_text:
By no measure is the United States third in total homicides or homicide rates. Excluding the named cities from the count had little to no impact on the United States’ international standing.

Three of the cities named in the meme are consistently the top cities for intentional homicides in the United States, but the other two are not. They are by no means outliers, either.

We rate this claim Pants on Fire!

fr_sentences.sentence_text: The United States is 3rd in murders throughout the world.
If you remove Chicago, Detroit, Washington, St. Louis and New Orleans, the United States is then 189th out of 193 countries in the entire world.

justification:
This statement is false. First, the claim that the United States ranks 3rd worldwide in total murders is misleading, as it confuses absolute numbers with per capita rates. Large countries like the U.S. will have higher total numbers due to population size, but murder rates are typically compared by cases per 100,000 people. According to United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC) data, the U.S. does not rank near the top in homicide rate per capita globally—many Latin American and African countries have much higher murder rates.

Additionally, removing several high-crime cities like Chicago, Detroit, Washington, St. Louis, and New Orleans would not drop the country to "189th out of 193 countries." These cities, while they have higher-than-average murder rates, represent a small proportion of the U.S. population and homicide total. Their removal would not drastically alter the overall national rate, which remains noticeably higher than most developed countries. This claim has been debunked by multiple fact-checkers, including PolitiFact and Snopes. Thus, the statement as presented is demonstrably false.

title: “It is a fact that Obama created ISIS.”
text: It is a fact that Obama created ISIS with the help of Israel. Israel also created Hamas. The west used the threat of Islamic terror to take our freedoms and invade the world. After destroying the Middle East the globalist then opened our borders and flooded us with jihadist.
claim: “It is a fact that Obama created ISIS.”
original_reasoning_text:
The inception of the Islamic State group once known as ISIS predates Barack Obama’s presidency, which started in 2009. The group’s terrorist creators and leaders have been well documented; Obama is not among them.

Experts have told PolitiFact that it could be argued Obama’s foreign policy and military decisions helped the Islamic State group expand in Iraq and Syria. Still, these actions did not "create" the terrorist group.

During his presidency, Obama prioritized targeting the terrorist group.

fr_sentences.sentence_text: It is a fact that Obama created ISIS with the help of Israel.

justification: The evaluation of "False" (F) for this news item is justified because its core claims are unfounded and widely debunked. There is no credible evidence that Barack Obama, Israel, or "the West" created ISIS; rather, ISIS (the Islamic State) emerged from the instability after the U.S. invasion of Iraq and the Syrian civil war, exploiting regional chaos and sectarian divides. Similarly, the claim that Israel created Hamas is misleading—while Israel once tolerated and indirectly aided the rise of Hamas’s predecessor groups in the 1980s as a counterweight to the secular PLO, it did not create Hamas, which grew as an indigenous Palestinian Islamist movement. The assertions about "globalists" deliberately flooding borders with jihadists are rooted in conspiracy theories without factual basis. The narrative that Western governments used terrorism threats solely as a pretext for invasions or rights abuses substantially misrepresents historical and political reality. In sum, these statements rely on conspiracy thinking and inaccurately represent complex geopolitical events, justifying the “False” rating.

title: “‘Satellites’ are on balloons and not in space.”
text:
Space is fake! Satellites hang from balloons. Space is fake and satellites are not in space they cant tell the public that.
Dont believe their china propaganda to promote the staged coming war.
FYI - This statement ⬆️⬆️ is the video creators, not mine….only sharing his view on the balloon.
claim: “‘Satellites’ are on balloons and not in space.”
original_reasoning_text:
Space is fake! Satellites hang from balloons. Space is fake and satellites are not in space they cant tell the public that.
Dont believe their china propaganda to promote the staged coming war.
FYI - This statement ⬆️⬆️ is the video creators, not mine….only sharing his view on the balloon.

fr_sentences.sentence_text: Satellites hang from balloons.
Space is fake and satellites are not in space they cant tell the public that.

justification:
The evaluation of "False" (F) is justified because the claim that "space is fake" and that "satellites hang from balloons" is entirely unfounded and contradicts overwhelming scientific evidence. The existence of space is a well-established fact, supported by centuries of astronomical observation, satellite technology, and international collaboration, such as the International Space Station (ISS), manned spaceflights, and images from space probes. Thousands of satellites are in orbit around Earth, performing functions like GPS, weather forecasting, and telecommunications; their orbits can be tracked in real time by anyone with the appropriate equipment or via public websites (e.g., CelesTrak, N2YO).

While there are scientific balloons used for high-altitude research, they do not reach the altitudes or perform the functions of satellites in space. The assertion that all satellites are mere balloons is easily disproved by physics (balloons cannot stay in stable Earth orbit), visual evidence (amateur astronomers and professionals regularly observe satellites), and the technical realities of satellite communication. Therefore, the statement is clearly false.

title: Soviet and Chinese communists have “grabbed control” of U.S. entertainment, movies, television, music, academia, K-12 education and the news media.
text:
This has been a long-term project by the left. It actually began in the 1930s, and it came out of the KGB (the former Russian secret police agency). It was a KGB operation to destroy the country. And then after World War II, the Soviets actually changed their tactics. And what they decided to do, and it’s been very effective for many decades, is infiltrate and grab control of the major pillars of U.S. life. They grabbed control of the culture — so entertainment, movies, television, music. They grabbed control of academia, at the university level and now it’s all the way shot down through kindergarten and even younger. And they grabbed control of the news media. 

With those pillars, they have been able to inflict tremendous damage over many decades. And now we are at a tipping point where the useful idiots on the left -- the Soviet Union collapsed, the CCP (Chinese Communist Party) stepped in to take over this grand project to destroy the country from within -- that’s exactly what’s happening. And now when you have useful idiots in the highest levels of power, including in the White House, including in Congress, you’re seeing an acceleration of the tipping point, to the point where we’re almost at the point of no return.
claim: Soviet and Chinese communists have “grabbed control” of U.S. entertainment, movies, television, music, academia, K-12 education and the news media.
original_reasoning_text:
The USSR, and to a lesser extent communist China, have sought to influence the U.S. over decades, including through spying and ideological persuasion. Some  Americans in entertainment, education, and the media were sympathetic to those ideas, primarily in the 1930s and 1940s.

However, none of these pillars of U.S. society were ever directly controlled by overseas communists, much less all of them, experts say. 

The real-life examples of communist influence in the U.S. are scattered and decades-old. In each of these sectors, active efforts by anti-communists purged those sympathetic to communism.

fr_sentences.sentence_text: And now we are at a tipping point where the useful idiots on the left -- the Soviet Union collapsed, the CCP (Chinese Communist Party) stepped in to take over this grand project to destroy the country from within -- that’s exactly what’s happening.

justification: The evaluation of "False" (F) for this news item is justified because there is no credible evidence supporting the claim that the KGB or Soviet Union orchestrated a long-term, coordinated plot to seize control of American cultural, educational, or media institutions. While it's historically accurate that the USSR conducted espionage and propaganda efforts during the Cold War, reputable historians, academic studies, and declassified documents do not support the extraordinary assertion of pervasive Soviet control over vast swathes of American society. Allegations that institutions like academia, entertainment, and media were "grabbed" and dominated by the KGB are rooted in conspiracy theories, notably the baseless "Cultural Marxism" narrative, rather than documented fact (see sources: The Atlantic, The New York Times, JSTOR articles on Cold War influence). The notion that the CCP later took over this same "grand project" is also unsupported by reliable intelligence or academic research. Therefore, the sweeping claims in the news item are demonstrably false, reflecting misinformation rather than documented history.

title: Bluetooth Earbuds Cause Brain Cancer?
text: Stop using  Apple AirPods. AirPods emit a dangerous amount of EMF radiation straight to your brain. This can potentially cause brain tumours and radiation poisoning. You know why they made iPhones without headphone jacks? So people will get the wireless  and fry their brains.
claim: The radiation from Bluetooth earbuds, such as AirPods, causes brain cancer.
original_reasoning_text:
Rumors that wireless devices can "cook" or "fry" one's brain appeared in 2015, when a group of more than 200 researchers signed an appeal to protect humans against "non-ionizing electromagnetic fields" (EMF). Their open letter mentioned, without citing, "numerous recent scientific publications" that allegedly suggested EMF might cause cancer and other harmful effects on cognition and the reproductive system, as well as in animals and plants. They called for authorities to create better guidelines and enforce stricter standards. As we reported in 2019, that open letter never mentions AirPods specifically, for a simple reason: In 2015, they did not exist.

The research has yet to find proof they're cancer-causing, or even a correlation between Bluetooth earbuds and poor health, as of the time of this writing.

fr_sentences.sentence_text: AirPods emit a dangerous amount of EMF radiation straight to your brain.

justification: The evaluation of "False" (F) for this news item is justified because there is no scientific evidence that Apple AirPods, or similar wireless earbuds, emit dangerous levels of electromagnetic field (EMF) radiation that cause brain tumors or radiation poisoning. Regulatory bodies such as the U.S. Federal Communications Commission (FCC) require all wireless devices, including AirPods, to adhere to strict limits on EMF emissions, ensuring that they are well below levels considered harmful to humans. Multiple reputable health organizations, including the World Health Organization (WHO), have repeatedly stated that there is no conclusive evidence linking the low-level EMF exposure from Bluetooth devices to cancer or other health risks. The claim that iPhones removed the headphone jack to “fry brains” is unfounded speculation with no basis in fact or industry statements. Therefore, the claims about AirPods causing brain tumors or substantial harm are not supported by science, justifying the "False" rating.

title: Is Jeff Bezos Building a '10,000 Year Clock' Costing $42M?
text: TIL Jeff Bezos is building a 10,000 Year Clock inside a remote mountain in West Texas an icon for long-term thinking. It ticks once a year, the century hand advances once every 100 years, and the cuckoo comes out on the millennium, and will keep time for the next 10,000 years.
claim: Amazon founder Jeff Bezos is building a $42 million clock that will keep time for 10,000 years.
original_reasoning_text:
In December 2011, Bezos published a first update on the construction of the 10,000 Year Clock. He explained a team of engineers had bored a 500-foot-deep hole into the Sierra Diablo mountain range in Texas, on land that he owns.

On the 10,000 Year Clock website, Bezos provided more details about the conception of the clock, explaining that he and The Long Now Foundation were hoping to make it a collaborative project with people in the future:

In 2018, Bezos announced on X (archived) that the installation of the clock mechanism had begun inside the shaft, adding a video: 

In June 2011, Bezos told Wired that he would invest $42 million in the clock. This is the number that has been used in successive reporting on the project, up to December 2023. As of this writing, no updates to this figure have been reported.

fr_sentences.sentence_text: It ticks once a year, the century hand advances once every 100 years, and the cuckoo comes out on the millennium, and will keep time for the next 10,000 years.
TIL Jeff Bezos is building a 10,000 Year Clock inside a remote mountain in West Texas an icon for long-term thinking.

justification: The evaluation of this news item as "True" is justified. Jeff Bezos is indeed supporting the construction of the "10,000 Year Clock," also known as the Long Now Clock, inside a remote mountain in West Texas. This project is managed by the Long Now Foundation, which aims to foster long-term thinking. The clock is being built inside a mountain on Bezos’ property in the Sierra Diablo range, and Bezos himself has invested $42 million in the initiative (sources: Long Now Foundation, BBC, Wired). The clock is designed to tick once a year, its century hand advances every 100 years, and a cuckoo appears every 1,000 years, as the news item describes. The intention is to create a symbol and reminder of the far future, and the technical elements reported in the news item accurately reflect public information shared by both Bezos and the Long Now Foundation. Therefore, the "True" rating corresponds with the factual details available from reputable sources.

title: Microsoft Announced It Will Disable Computers of Users Who Share 'Non-Mainstream Content' Online?
text:
Microsoft To Disable Computers of Users Who Share ‘Non-Mainstream Content’ Online<annotate_paragraph>

Microsoft has announced plans to disable the computers of people who share ‘non-mainstream’ content online, in an attempt to combat so-called ‘misinformation’ in the run-up to the 2024 election. 

During an interview with NBC’s Lester Holt, Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella was questioned about how AI might either assist or endanger the future election.

Reclaimthenet.org reports: However, Nadella’s response seemed to imply a willingness to use technology for censoring content in pursuit of fighting what he identified as disinformation.

Nadella stated, “This is not the first election where we dealt with disinformation or propaganda campaigns by adversaries and election interference.
“We’re doing all the work across the tech industry around watermarking, detecting deep fakes and content IDs. There is going to be enough and more technology quite frankly in order to be able to identify the issues around disinformation and misinformation.”
claim: Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella said in early 2024 that the company plans to disable the computers of users who share "non-mainstream content" online.
original_reasoning_text:
However, this rumor was both false and misleading, despite a label next to the headline that said the story had been "fact-checked."

One user commented under The People's Voice article, "Your headline has absolutely no merit based on the information you provide as context. Are you trying to mislead?"

Further, Gates, who stepped down as Microsoft's CEO in 2000 and left the company's board in 2020, was not once mentioned in the story, despite being featured in the picture below the headline.
